newsitem.title: USA: Silicon Valley firm puts "Push" to corporate use.
newsitem.headline: Silicon Valley firm puts "Push" to corporate use.

text.p: Amid a rash of companies attempting to use so-called "push" technology to win consumers' attention on a crowded World Wide Web, one firm is marketing the technology for a behind-the-scenes business product.

"Push," arguably the Internet technology du jour, is a method of distributing information over the Internet so it goes automatically -- like a broadcast -- to people who have registered interest in the topic. It's often marketed as an alternative to the tedium of searching for information.

Quintus Corp, a Fremont, California, based maker of customer service software, recently introduced software joining push technology and so-called intranets for customer service application. Intranets are internal corporate networks based on the Internet.

Its "ImpaQ" software is designed to let key employees within a company get real-time information about customers "pushed" to them at vital moments from in-house databases or from partners' databases over intranets.
Using the information, a sales person might, for example, prevent a customer defection by resolving a problem of a missed shipment before the customer calls to complain.

"Customer service is at the core of most (companies') challenges," Quintus President Alan Anderson said in an interview. "In the future, the only thing that is going to differentiate a company is its customer service."
Quintus likes to cite a potential use for ImpaQ in the hotel business.

For example, a hotel with an intranet-to-Intranet data-sharing arrangement with an airline gets information flashed to it that a registered guest's flight arrived late. The hotel, Anderson said, could respond by being ready for the weary traveller when she arrives and prevent a wait in the check-in line and the risk of an angry guest.

"I believe the hospitality industry will subscribe to this fairly aggressively. "Customer service is a problem for hotels and airlines," that both industries are already spending heavily to fix, he said.
Hilton Hotels Corp is a Quintus customer for its other customer service products, Anderson said. He said when Hilton officials were briefed on the product they "did a back flip".

Another example might be a pharmaceutical firm's sales and shipping departments getting notices "pushed" to them the moment a pharmacy runs out of its product. The pharmaceutical firm would then be able to replenish the stock before the pharmacy has time to ponder switching vendors.

Privately-held Quintus, which sells other customer service and call centre software, operates in a market place populated with many vendors, the largest of which are probably Verity Inc and Clarify Inc, analysts said.
But the market is growing fast for all -- about 40 percent a year, Gartner Group estimates.

Quintus hopes to differentiate itself -- at least temporarily -- as the only customer service software seller to use push technology on private intranets, analysts said, to offer real-time pervasive customer information. Verity offers an e-mail notification service using the Internet.

"This is a very functionality driven marketplace. Quintus is the first one to come out with this sort of technology, this functionality, of making customer information pervasively available within an organisation," said Gartner Group analyst Carter Lusher, vice president and research director for customer service and support strategies.
"What is unique is it's centred on better information flow for customer management," said META Group analyst Kurt Johnson.
And Quintus becomes the first company to use Push technology in a purely business-to-business purpose using closed intranets.

PointCast Inc has made "push" technology successful among consumers and professionals wanting World Wide Web-based information searched for them with certain topics then "pushed" to their computers. Quintus plans to make the software generally available in the second quarter of the year.
